stream_context.summary: Kaze continues getting the demo close to release-ready while actively developing Course 15’s “space/arcade” area: performance testing on emulators and real N64, fixing rendering/texture issues, and implementing new traversal mechanics (custom warp platforms and low-gravity zones). A major thread is a hypothetical parallel release: reskinning the game into an original IP version (with movement changes) to legally sell on Steam, potentially using N64 Recomp, and replacing remaining inefficient Nintendo code.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a major business/legal strategy discussion (parallel original-IP Steam release) alongside concrete gameplay-feature implementation (warp animation redesign, low-gravity volumes) and N64 performance/compatibility testing.

findings.summary: Kaze floats a serious-sounding (but still hypothetical) plan to ship RTYI as-is, and also create a separate version that is ~90% the same content but with all Nintendo IP replaced by original characters/assets and some movement changes, enabling legal ownership and potential Steam sales (possibly via N64 Recomp).
findings.quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own? That is the idea. And that way we would legally own it.

findings.summary: He notes an accessibility/marketing argument for a Steam release: players may feel ROM hacks require technical knowledge, whereas a cheap standalone on Steam would lower friction and broaden reach.
findings.quote: People might be apprehensive about playing the Mario 64, or they might think that they need to be like tech nerds to even boot up a Mario 64. But if we just put it on Steam and you can get it for like 5 bucks, then easy.

findings.summary: Kaze emphasizes that some very low-level code cannot be avoided in an N64 project (cache invalidation, RCP task submission, CP0 register reads), pushing back on the idea that everything can be clean C; he frames this as OS-level necessity for the platform.

He says some original Nintendo code still remains, but he plans to replace it—partly for legal/independence reasons and partly because he believes Nintendo’s original implementation is inefficient and hard to work with.
findings.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.

findings.summary: Physical cartridge release is framed as unrealistic without rights to Super Mario 64; he jokes about Nintendo granting rights, implying cartridge plans are blocked by licensing constraints.
findings.quote: To make a physical card, I would need the rights to Super Mario 64 first. I don't have them currently.

findings.summary: Demo packaging/status: he says he’s been getting the demo “mostly release ready” off-stream; Delfino will be a secret level in the demo (expected many won’t unlock). He still gives no demo date and later suggests he likely won’t release for Christmas to avoid overlapping another creator’s holiday release (“Robot”).

Performance and hardware testing: he shows the level running with worst-case ~22–25 FPS in a heavy view, argues it’s acceptable (and comparable to some vanilla SM64 areas), and demonstrates booting on real N64. He notes the build is not stable yet (crashes) but considers it fixable.
Art pipeline and division of labor: he uses Blender (via the Fast64 plugin) and explicitly avoids spending too long on temporary textures because Biobak is expected to rework/replace them anyway.
findings.quote: Probably shouldn't spend so much time on textures and stuff. Considering Biobak is reworking all my stuff anyway. I should just leave it to him.

findings.summary: Warp platform feature: he starts from existing “fading warp” behavior but rejects Mario transparency because it breaks with their current materials/visual pipeline. He disables Mario’s transparency behavior/flags (also citing extra processing) and implements a new warp look using scaling/transformation-matrix manipulation, plus a plan for under-lighting when standing on the platform.

Difficulty/structure philosophy: he likes placing very hard optional challenges late-game, but recognizes players often run into them early and get frustrated, so he wants to gate or present these challenges more carefully. He also describes the game as potentially “looking harder” than SM64 due to platforming, but balancing that with more consistent movement.
findings.quote: The problem with that is that a lot of the time players do encounter it. And then they're like, this sucks, this is way too difficult, I hate this game. So I wanna prevent that.

findings.summary: He adds/activates a low-gravity zone (visualized like a moving light/beam cage) and describes this as a flexible actor he can place anywhere. He notes certain animation constraints (Mario animations effectively run at 30), limiting options like slowing/altering timing without expensive interpolation.

biobak.summary: Kaze frames Biobak as the person who will rework/replace current textures and visual work, influencing Kaze’s decision to avoid over-investing in interim art assets during this phase.

zeina.summary: Zeina is credited with creating the new carpet texture (and related text/graphics) for the arcade/cinema-lobby vibe; Kaze showcases it as a key piece of the level’s look.
zeina.quote: What do you think of this carpet that Zeina made? Pretty cool, eh?

zeina.summary: Zeina appears in chat; Kaze references the baby sleeping with her while she’s working, briefly situating development inside family life.

findings.summary: Kaze references trusting Wiseguy’s N64 Recomp work, which underpins his interest in a dual-release strategy (real N64 + modern storefront).
Kaze implies he may delay his demo release to avoid colliding with Robot’s Christmas release, showing coordination/consideration within the broader creator ecosystem.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: What if, along with RTYI, I also release a game that is 90% the same content, but we replace all the Nintendo IP with our own? That is the idea. And that way we would legally own it.
memorable_quotes.context: He discusses a parallel original-IP version as a legal path to a Steam release and broader distribution.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The problem with that is that a lot of the time players do encounter it. And then they're like, this sucks, this is way too difficult, I hate this game. So I wanna prevent that.
memorable_quotes.context: He explains his tension between loving extreme optional difficulty and protecting the average player experience.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There is some original Nintendo code left, but I am planning to replace it. Not even because I want to replace all the Nintendo code, just because the code is complete dog ass.
memorable_quotes.context: A blunt statement tying reverse-engineering/rewriting to both quality and independence from Nintendo’s legacy code.

key_stories.title: Considering a parallel original-IP version for Steam
key_stories.summary: While preparing RTYI’s demo, Kaze explores a second product track: keeping the same core game structure but replacing Nintendo IP with original characters/assets and tweaking movement so it functions as a distinct, owned title. He ties this to reducing player friction (no ROM-hack setup) and to potential Steam distribution via N64 Recomp.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI is inherently tied to Nintendo IP and a ROM-hack-style distribution model that can limit reach and raises legal constraints around selling/physical releases.
key_stories.process: He proposes asset/IP replacement plus mechanical changes, notes he already has an original main character concept, and frames Recomp/Steam as a technical and marketing path while keeping a distinction between an N64 version and a modern version.
key_stories.outcome: No commitment yet—he labels it hypothetical—but it becomes a concrete strategic option he’s actively weighing.
key_stories.key_quote: People might be apprehensive about playing the Mario 64... But if we just put it on Steam and you can get it for like 5 bucks, then easy.

key_stories.title: Redesigning warp visuals to avoid Mario transparency issues
key_stories.summary: Kaze implements new warp platforms for Course 15, but finds the intended fading/transparent effect breaks visuals due to the project’s current materials/render setup. He pivots to an animation approach that avoids transparency and also reduces unnecessary processing.
key_stories.challenge: Mario’s transparency behavior conflicts with the hack’s material pipeline and causes visual breakage during warp transitions.
key_stories.process: He disables Mario transparency usage/flags, then implements a scaling/transformation-matrix-based warp effect (Mario scales into the floor) and plans under-lighting to sell the effect.
key_stories.outcome: A working warp platform effect that fits the project’s rendering constraints and becomes a reusable interaction for the level.

open_questions.topic: Parallel original-IP release scope and legal positioning
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a second version of the game with Nintendo IP replaced and movement changed, potentially sold on Steam via N64 Recomp, while still shipping RTYI as a Mario-based hack.
questions: How far did this idea progress beyond a stream thought—did you prototype any reskin/original-character version or write a design doc?
What would you change mechanically (movement, physics, level beats) to ensure it’s not just an asset swap?
What legal advice (if any) did you seek on the line between homage/derivative work and an original, sellable title built from the decomp base?
Would the Steam version share the same codebase as RTYI, or would it fork early to reduce Nintendo code/IP exposure?
How would you message the relationship between RTYI and the original-IP version to avoid confusing players (and to respect SM64’s legacy)?

open_questions.context: He states some original Nintendo code remains and he plans to replace it, citing both code quality and implicit legal/independence motivations.
questions: Which subsystems still contain original Nintendo code today (OS layer, rendering, physics, animation, collision, audio)?
What’s your practical definition of ‘replaced’—rewriting functions one-by-one, swapping whole modules, or isolating them behind new interfaces?
Did you benchmark any rewrites to quantify the cycle savings you mention (before/after numbers, profiling method on real hardware vs emulator)?
How do you decide when low-level assembly is worth keeping versus rewriting for maintainability?

open_questions.topic: Demo scope and release timing constraints
open_questions.context: He says the demo is being made mostly release-ready, includes Delfino as a secret, but he may avoid a Christmas release to not overlap Robot’s launch.
questions: What is the final intended content list for the demo (courses, secret unlock rules for Delfino, overworld content, side levels)?
What criteria makes the demo ‘ready’ for you—stability, performance on real N64, a minimum number of polished actors, or playtest feedback?
How did Robot’s release affect your calendar in practice—did you actually delay, and was that a strategic decision (audience overlap) or personal courtesy?
What are the biggest remaining blockers you remember at this point in development (crashes, memory, missing actors, art pass, camera, etc.)?

open_questions.topic: Playtesting approach: ‘send demos to one person’ loop
open_questions.context: Kaze describes a personal workflow of repeatedly sending demos to one tester to gather feedback and iterate, framing it as playtesting efficiency.
questions: Who is the primary tester in this loop, and why do you trust their feedback style?
What kind of feedback do you request (difficulty, clarity, performance, ‘fun factor’), and how do you capture it (notes, videos, bug list)?
At what point do you broaden testing beyond one person, and what risks have you seen with too-narrow playtest demographics?

open_questions.topic: Course 15 mechanic set and intended ‘arcade in space’ fantasy
open_questions.context: He’s building a large arcade building, moving colorful light beams, scrolling pixel art floors, warp platforms, and low-gravity zones, but notes that turning it into fun platforming will be hard.
questions: What is the core player fantasy for this level—precision platforming, spectacle traversal, puzzle navigation, or ‘toybox’ experimentation?
Which mechanics are essential (low gravity, warps, bumpers/flippers/pinball pieces) and which are at risk of being cut?
You mention wanting eight red coins mostly below the structure—what’s the intended route and difficulty curve for first-time players?
How do you prevent the level from feeling like ‘Portal 2’ visually/mechanically while keeping the sci-fi arcade theme?
